name: Sword of the Stars II: Enhanced Edition
description: The Enhanced Edition contains Sword of the Stars II: The Lords of Winter and the first expansion, the End of Flesh. The new expansion introduces the new playable race, the Loa. All previous DLCs containing new avatars, new combat music, alternate voices, skins, and new badges for the warships are also included.

reviews.review_text: Let me start by saying this: I would normally NOT recommend this game to people. I'm kind of weird in the fact that buggy games don't bother me too much, and I have a lot of patience for unfinished games or games with unrealized potential. I also have to restart the game every few hours if I'm doing a long play session because of memory leaks, and I have 24 Gigs of RAM. This game's a technical nightmare, and isn't receiving support from the publisher anymore. The developer still exists, but is hanging on by a thread.  I recommend, if you're even interested in this game, to check out the first game. It is easier to learn, and very stable. It would be awesome to see this game finished, but it won't happen anytime soon, if at all.  I think one of the biggest tragedies of this game is simply the lore and the story. This game has no campaign, only custom scenarios, like most other 4x games. The game includes what's called a Sotspedia that's more in depth about things than other comparitve things like Mass Effect's codex. The lore behind the major factions/races is inredibly deep. In fact, I own a book that takes place in this universe.  This is also evident in how each faction/race has not just their own strengths and weaknesses, but they have completely different methods of FTL travel, which has a huge impact on the gameplay. Things from the Tarka's standard warp drive, the Hiver's gate network for instant teleportation once they slowboat it to new systems and set up a gate, to the Liir's stutterwarp drives, using thousands of teleportations a second to move, increasing in speed the further away from gravity wells they get. They're all pretty interesting. And there's 7 of these factions.  But, again, I cannot recommend this game unless you're hardcore into this genre, and want to find what is, perhaps, both a hidden, yet flawed and tarnished gem. I love this game so much, but I cannot just tell people to check it out. I want them to consider this game, while informed.  If you're at all interested, I recommend checking out the wiki. It has a lot of helpful and interesting information.

The other reviews of this game are quite old by now. The game has updated plenty since release, fixing many of the bugs and performance issues other reviewers were having.  While not the same as the original Sword of the Stars, SotS 2 is a great 4x game. It adds a great amount of complexity and diversity to the already diverse SotS formula. The fleet command interface is strange compared to the original SotS but once you get used to it it is quite reasonable.   The only problem I have with this game (besides some minor interface quirks) is the AI. As other people have complained, the AI has a tendency to just camp around its homeworlds for the entire game. But this, however, does not mean that the AI will be sedantary. The AI will send you fleets composed of a dozen different designs, making the tech to see the loadouts of enemy ships completely useless, because the AI never ♥♥♥♥in' sticks to any one design.

This game has come along way since its disastrous launch, however I'd still peg it at being somewhere in the late beta stage. Some interfaces don't work right, other features are still broken, diplomacy is mostly an afterthought, and you'll still experience the odd crash to desktop. With all that said, once you learn the interface and how the fleet system works it can still be an enjoyable experience. Buy on sale if you're a fan of the original, but be aware that developer support has officially ended.

It's a love hate relationship. Of all the 4x games, this one had the most potential but since it was never finished, it went into obscurity. I love the game even in its unfinished state. It has the best tactical battle system of all other 4x space games as well as the most innovative races and tech tree. However there it ends. Everything else is half finished and not polished, riddled with bugs. I still spent countless hours in this game, just for the fleet battles. :)   Only recommeded for die hard 4x fans.

If you liked the original, now's a good time to try the sequel! Most of the bugs that plagued the intial release have been fixed, an heavy optimisations have been put in place.  while the learning curve and not-so intuitive UI may put off some, once you get used to it it revelas itself to be a deeper game than even the original. An in game chat is available if you ever need advice or tips. The community there is usually friendly.

After many of the bugs and system issues seem to be fixed the game worked well. lots of time went into making a more detailed and visually pleasing game over Sots 1. A much slower build up to a vast empire but you have many more options. As much as I like it I enjoy Sword of The Stars 1 over 2. You can buy the complete 1 for a steal. It plays fast and has a very robust networking allowing reentry after a turn is done. the ai on both work well and gives you a run for your money.  SOTS 2 is worth playing for anyone who likes the genre but SOTS 1 is a better buy with lan capability and direct mp play thorugh ip addresses as It needed Gamespy for mp games which is long gone.
Overall a solid game, but not great game. UI is total ♥♥♥, but the graphics are pretty. It's one of the very very few modern 4x's out there though.

When this game was released, it was one of the increasing number of games that were seemingly published before they were ready. I didn't get the game then, because of all the reported bugs, and because I had no cash.  But about a year after it was published, I had a bit of money, and I thought the game was ready, so Ibought it. While steam says I've spent about 55 hours playing this game so far, because I have been without internet for a good portion of the time I have owned the game, I probably have put more like two or three hundred hours in.  If you like the 4X genre of grand strategy games, or turned based strategy games with real-time tactics in general, I think that this game is the one for you. It's got lots of complex mechanics that allow for an interesting, irrepeatible gameplay experience.  My main gripe about this game, compared to its predecessor, is the tech tree. I think that the study feasiblity mechanic was not the best way to make the tree semi-random. Also, the effect of some techs seem to be a bit questionable, whether or not they actually do anything.  But on the whole, I would recommend this for anyone who has played Sword of the Stars Prime, or anyone who enjoys this genre of games.

As you can tell by the hours I invested in this game, I really enjoy Sword of the Stars II: Enhanced Addition. Like with any game and game upgrade, it's a learning process. SOTS II is a much more involved and complex game than it's predesesor, SOTS I. Still, I am learning the operation and control of the game as I go along.  A few things I need to mention, the pluses. Of course, a lot better graphics goes a long way. I also like the variety of settings that it comes with. The ship design function is great, at least to me. The possiility of colonizing multiple planets in a star system is a great concept as well. Another plus is the having a Squadron CnC direct control of the Fleets, commanded by an Admiral.  You may wonder what I would like to see added (again) or improved:  1) I would like to see more Stellar systems (up to 350-like the old SOTS) 2) I liked the way the trade software operated in the old SOTS: 1 3) I liked the idea of sharing technology with allies. 4) I liked observing my allies combat segments 5) I would like my spies to be able to steal technology from the enemy.

The game is not perfect but it is the most comprehensive and satisfying 4x game after the original Sots. It's hard to master but as it stands it's a great game once you understand how to be successful, (building freighters and trade stations early on is key). I own a PS4 and other games but I have still come back to this game.
I like this game =).

Man does this game have depth. It's like playing Civ 5 on steriods. There are only 2 real downsides to the game an one is more like a good downside. One is that it is very in depth, so some people who one a more pick up an play sorta relaxed game this is not it. Secondly its being constantly changed and upgraded, which sadly leads to bugs, but they get patched extremely fast, and that means the game is constantly getting better. Now onto the good parts...  Multiple Races that are very diffrent, want to play as a super agressive race, the Horde can't even engage in diplomacy! They only accept slaves as a payment to not attack now, but later. There is literally a race for every play style.  Tech is also a huge part of the game, and every race can litterally learn every tech, with one small exception. Certain races excell at certain techs, so a race that is horrible at missle technology will begin to research the Tech, then after a turn or 2 be told if they have a chance of researching it or if its just not possible. And even if you are good at a particula tech you may still be told its not possible, so every game is diffrent locking you out an allowing you other tech tress.  Faster then Light travel is important since the galaxy is a big place, and every race way of travelling is vastly diffrent then the other. Being able to move from any star system increasing in speed the farther you are from a star, or constructing warp gates to literally warp from one side of the galaxy to the other wherever you have a gateway, to having node lines interconnecting each star an following them.   Trade, science, exploration, war. This games got it all.

I like this game, but there are still alot of bugs in it... i have play it a lot and find it to my likening, and also is a good game, but there are some ting there need alot of work, like the AI, is BAD  but a good game, if you play mulitiplay with it...

Having played Sword Of the Stars I felt this should be there right next to it.  They did a fair job at complicating systems, extending the game as it was, and with commanders now having experience and getting promoted as well as ship modules that further define a ships capabilities they did all right.  Unfortunately they took out the tutorials, which, with this new interface they probably should have extended upon, the encyclopedia is full of spelling errors and looks as though its a fan-production (or at least I hope it is, having seen Star Trek Enterprise it seems all so familiar) that they decided to implement into the game, and then there is the Research screen, which I always had a problem with, even in the first version. The having to confirm some aspects to research but not others... I'm affraid to touch any slider in the game now just because there might be a hidden confirm button I'll need to find first...not the kind of easter eggs I was hoping for.  I loved the first game, but I'm not sure what I should be calling...this...  On the up-side, I haven't experienced a single crash people are (still) going on about.

SOTS II can and, is in my opinion a great game. But for the average person, this game is just not something to purchase, even if it has improved leaps and bounds since launch.  There are still way to many issues, mainly how confusing it can be to a new player. The biggest issue I have is turn times, especially in bigger games, and when turns get into the triple digits.  Now don't get me wrong, I greatly enjoy this game, and I would love to tell people to pick it up and just try, but I can't.

This game is a shame. I switched off the Steam overlay to counter the crash to desktop per 30 mins. I battled my way through the painful management. This game is an abomination against all that is good.  Many people may have fond memories of Sword of the Stars I, which is a fun game. Sadly, this game will only serve to tarnish your memories of fun and joy and replace them with anger, sadness, and a sense of puzzlement as to what could have possibly possessed the developers to make such a steaming pile of feces.  The game is filled with....curious...design decisions. Such as the opening techs taking 30+ turns to research. Or the fact that designing a new warship requires you to destroy half your treasury to change one gun. Neither of these problems were present in the original game, The UI is confusing and bad, and even the free expansion pack does not serve to improve it.  Avoid this game and go play the original game or Galactic Civilizations.

SotS II is an actively worse game than its predicessor.  While I enjoyed the heck out of the first one, the second one is not only was buggy, but is flat out unfun to play due to its snail place, poor AI implimentation, and horrible interface/UI.  A sequel should never be a worse game than the one that preceeded it. I'm a pretty big fan of SotS, and I got royally screwed when I purchased the hard copy of Prime. Seems nothing has been learned from that experience. As with Prime SotS2 was as broken as it could on release with more features not working than did. Kerberos made Prime into a great game with its DLC's (though kinda screwed over their initial customers). This seemed to be going into the same direction, but it isnt.  SotS2 is a very nice looking game with a number of really interesting features. However, it still is a very unfinished product and it is very clear Kerberos stopped development. Which would not be that bad if the AI would be able to put up a good fight, specially late game. The AI however can only seem to be able to destroy its own economy.  The default routine for the AI when set to hard is sort of like the following: -Heavy on research, colonization second (you'll easilly outgrow the AI even if you allow the AI to start with 6 planets, even when playing as Hiver). -When the AI meets you, 1-3 turns later it will declare war on you. -AI goes into overdrive redesigning ships and kills its economy trying to build these redesigned ships. -As a results you'll find yourself spammed with small/halfbuild fleets even when you have Leviathans on defense.  Also, research is basicly the same as in Prime. No you dont have to research cruisers, but it is still the same as in Prime as now you just have an extra stage attached to the end. However the extra strage (Leviathans) are boring, slow, strategicly only usefull on defense. Specially so since you can build as many Flagships as you like and below the math: Leviathan: 54CP cost, can fit 2 in a fleet with 2 Dreads or add 5 Dreads. Flagship: 18CP cost, can fit an additional 6 Dreads in the fleet.  Since the Flagship has better speed and is much more affordable you have the choice between a moderatly expensive 7 Dreads-Fleet (Flagship), or a hugelly expensive 1 Leviathan + 5 Dreads-Fleet.  All and all, as a game that should entertain I recommend you stay clear of this and try something else. If you do not care about a (semi-)competitive game, or intend to only use it in MP, it sure is worth €15-ish. I sure do advice you turn of random events and mod out pirates .. boy are those annoying features!

Why does Sword of the Stars II not have a rudimental tutorial to explain the complex gameplay? Simple, making a tutorial would have meant testing it and the Kerberos sure as hell didn't want to play their game.  Yet another pile of trash on Paradox' portfolio.
